com.wizarpos.devices.msr
Interface MSRControl

All Superinterfaces:
DeviceControl, TimeConstants
public interface MSRControl
extends DeviceControl, TimeConstants

The MSRControl interface defines the magnetic stripe reader APIs to be used by the applications.

A control instance is obtained from the Device Manager with no specific service association. The control is associated with a device through a call to open(), passing the device logical ID. This association is lost when close() is called on the service control.

MSR device is an exclusive device. It can't be opened again if it's already opened.

Version:
July 01, 2013
Author:
Haiqing Jin

listenForSwipe

void listenForSwipe(OperationListener listener)
                    throws DeviceException
Initiates the operation to obtain the data read from selected tracks. The listenForSwipe request will complete and generate the resulted operation result once a new card has been swiped AFTER this request was posted. In order to ensure the integrity of data, listenForSwipe() first reinitializes any existing card data buffer that may have been created by previous card swipings, before waiting for a new card to be swiped. No effective reading of the card tracks will be done until a request is pending.

This method is asynchronous and results in an MSROperationResult sent to the handleResult method of the OperationListener. On success, the read data can be retrieved using the operation result's getData method.

Throws:
DeviceException - for the standard reasons that are documented in DeviceException.
See Also:
OperationListener.handleResult(com.wizarpos.devices.OperationResult), MSROperationResult, MSRCardData

waitForSwipe

MSROperationResult waitForSwipe(int timeout)
                                throws DeviceException
Synchronous method for retrieve card data.

This method will block the invoker's thread until timeout, data arrived or canceled by another thread.

Parameters:
timeout - the maximum pending time of the method, in milliseconds. Note that the timeout will begin when the request begins to be processed. The timeout parameter is then only indicative. There are two special cases for timeout, as follows:
  • If timeout == FOREVER, the method will wait until something is available on the associated service's input.
  • If timeout == IMMEDIATE, the method will immediately read the input
Returns:
the result of swiping
Throws:
DeviceException
